newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish insurer Amplico ups '96 net to PLN 18.6 mln.
newsitem.headline: Polish insurer Amplico ups '96 net to PLN 18.6 mln.

text.p: Polish life insurer Amplico Life SA lifted its net profit to 18.6 million zlotys last year from 5.1 million zlotys in 1995, the company's president said on Friday.

Georges Dourte told a news conference Amplico Life's gross premium rose to 205.9 million zlotys last year from 85.7 million zlotys in 1995 and that it had gained a 7.5 percent market share. In 1995 the firm's market share was estimated at about 4.5 percent.
It said the number of clients doubled last year to 244,489.
Dourte said the company would see similar growth this year.
"We will continue for sure at the cruising speed we were enjoying in 1996. Our strategy for 1997 is that we continue at the same speed of expansion across the country," Dourte said.

Amplico is 55-percent owned by the U.S.-based American Insurance Group (AIG) and 45-percent owned by Polish state-owned Bank Pekao SA, which last year raised the firm's share capital to 11 million zlotys from two million zlotys.
Amplico also lifted its technical result last year to 13.6 million zlotys from 2.5 million zlotys in 1995 and increased revenues from investment to 27.4 million from 10.7 million.
Kendall Nottingham, AIG senior vice president, would not comment on rumours that Pekao would pull out of Amplico.

"We really have no comment on the future nature of that relationship which I think will be largely driven by Polish government decisions and reorganisations that have yet to be announced," Nottingham told the news conference.

Pekao has formed a group with three other state-owned commercial banks and its privatisation is slated for next year. It has been also named among potential investors in the state-owned Powszechny Zaklad Ubezpieczen (PZU) insurer, which plans to start its privatisation by offering new shares to selected institutions.
Nottingham told Reuters Amplico would have no problems operating as a wholly-owned subsidiary, if necessary.
